metadata.sermon_title: Trinity Sunday / Second Sunday After Pentecost
metadata.notes: The text focuses on the nature of the Trinity as self-giving love and the necessity of acknowledging human 'miserable' status to receive mercy.

freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.score_explanation: 10 = Completely free from coercive judgments. 0 = Very dominant Critical Parent.
freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.analysis: The preacher utilizes a strong Critical Parent voice to enforce a 'miserable offender' identity. Coercion manifests as an intellectual demand to accept a 'vast primordial catastrophe' of the self.
quotes: there is no health in us
the depth of which the psalmist is actually speaking here is the depth of the knowledge that he and everyone else is a 'miserable offender'

healthy_care_NP.score_explanation: 10 = Healthy, non-smothering care. 0 = Absent or smothering.
healthy_care_NP.analysis: The Nurturing Parent is present in the imagery of the desperate parent, but it is used as a psychological hook to justify the Critical Parent's subsequent diagnosis of the listener's 'wretchedness'.
quotes: You would make a complete fool of yourself if you thought it might get your child’s attention.

adult.analysis: The Adult is used primarily to analyze historical texts and liturgy (the 1976 Prayer Book changes), but it does not invite the listener to test reality; rather, it dictates a theological reality the listener must accept.
quotes: The removal of this line has robbed us of a powerful buttress to the biblical concept of sin.

freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.score_explanation: 10 = Free from fear/compliance. 0 = Strong Adapted Child (fear culture).
freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.analysis: The sermon explicitly invites the listener into the Adapted Child position—specifically the 'compliant' and 'shamed' child who must admit they have 'no health' to be accepted.
quotes: Before God, none of us can hold up our heads.

free_child_FC.analysis: There is a brief attempt at Free Child 'joy' at the end, but it is conditional and follows a heavy session of self-abasement.

transaction_analysis.analysis: The preacher establishes a Parent-Child dynamic by using the 'desperate parent' analogy to mirror God/Paul, then shifts to Critical Parent to diagnose the 'miserable' state of the listener (Child).
transaction_analysis.ulterior_motives: The social transaction is 'I am teaching you about the Trinity/Psalms' (A->A). The psychological transaction is 'You are sick and wretched, and only my diagnosis can save you' (P->C).
transaction_analysis.risk_explanation: The 'Bait & Switch' risk is high: the sermon starts with the 'Love of God' (NP) but quickly pivots to the necessity of feeling 'miserable' (CP).

detected_games.name: ITHY (I'm Only Trying To Help You)

formula_g_analysis.con: God's love is like a parent who would do anything for you.
formula_g_analysis.gimmick: The listener's desire for unconditional love and fear of being 'lost'.
formula_g_analysis.switch: The preacher shifts from 'love' to 'you are a miserable offender with no health in you'.
formula_g_analysis.payoff: The listener feels guilty/small; the preacher feels the 'merit' of being the one to deliver the hard truth.

evidence_quotes: The less we deserve, the more merit is in his bounty.

detected_games.name: NIGYSOB (Now I've Got You, You Son of a Bitch)

formula_g_analysis.con: Let's look at the beauty of the Trinity.
formula_g_analysis.gimmick: The listener's sense of moral failure.
formula_g_analysis.switch: Pointing out that even the 'good' people are 'miserable offenders' and 'none can stand'.
formula_g_analysis.payoff: Total psychological submission of the congregation.

evidence_quotes: not just the bigots and thugs... but with all of us. Before God, none of us can hold up our heads.

preacher_roles.rescuer: High. The preacher offers the 'path of life' through the specific confession of wretchedness.
preacher_roles.persecutor: Medium. Labels the congregation as 'miserable offenders' and critiques those who 'do not want to hear it'.
preacher_roles.victim: Low. Paul is framed as the victim of the Corinthians' rejection to build sympathy.

drama_triangle_analysis.congregation_position: Victim. The congregation is told they are in a 'vast primordial catastrophe' and have 'no health' in them.
drama_triangle_analysis.escape_possibilities: Minimal. The only 'escape' offered is through further submission to the Parent's diagnosis.

conclusion_and_recommendation.summary: While theologically traditional, the sermon is psychologically coercive. it relies on the 'I'm OK, You're Not OK' position. It uses the Nurturing Parent (the 'desperate parent' analogy) to lower the listener's defenses before delivering a Critical Parent blow regarding their 'wretchedness.' The insistence on the phrase 'no health in us' functions as a tool to induce regression into a dependent Adapted Child state.
strengths: Strong use of metaphor to engage the Nurturing Parent/Child bond.
Clear historical Adult-level analysis of liturgical changes.
areas_for_improvement: Lack of Adult-to-Adult invitation for the listener to find their own meaning in the text.
conclusion_and_recommendation.advice_for_game_free_communication: Try addressing the congregation as Adult subjects capable of choosing goodness, rather than 'miserable' objects. Shift from 'You must feel wretched to be saved' to 'How does God's love empower your current reality?'
